docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As a medical writer, I am concerned by the lack of attention being paid to two important issues involved in the recent case of the baby who received a baboon heart. The first is that no one I am aware of has mentioned the fact that, despite the impression created by the doctors at Loma Linda University Medical Center, there is indeed another option open to infants with hypoplastic left heart syndrome. It might also be considered experimental, but far less so than a xenograft (cross-species transplant). I refer to a two-stage operation developed by doctors at Boston Children's Hospital and reported in the medical literature. After listening to news accounts and reading Lawrence K. Altman's stories, I decided to pursue that angle. Specifically, I wanted to inquire about the baby boy the group had reported on in the Jan. 6, 1983, issue of the New England Journal of Medicine.

headline.main: LESS DRAMATIC REMEDY FOR BABY FAE CASES
